questions.text:
Smoking increases the risk of which of the following diseases?


	Duct ectasia
	Fibroadenoma
	Mondor disease
	Breast carcinoma
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) 1, 3, 4

Explanation:

  • Smoking is not directly associated with an increased risk of fibroadenomas, which are benign breast tumours often occurring in younger women.
  • Smoking increases the risk of duct ectasia, Mondor disease, and breast carcinoma, but not fibroadenoma.

Duct ectasia refers to the dilation or enlargement of the milk ducts in the breast, often leading to inflammation and possible discharge. It is often seen in older women, particularly during menopause. Smoking is considered a risk factor for this condition as it contributes to vascular changes and may affect the ducts.

Mondor's disease is a rare condition that involves thrombophlebitis (inflammation of veins caused by blood clots) of the superficial veins in the breast or chest area. Smoking has been linked to vascular changes, which may increase the likelihood of developing Mondor’s disease.

Smoking is a well-established risk factor for breast cancer, especially in postmenopausal women.

questions.text: In patients at risk of refeeding syndrome, which of the following electrolyte imbalances is typically not associated with this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Hyperkalemia

Explanation:

Hyperkalemia is not typically associated with refeeding syndrome. In fact, potassium levels usually decrease during refeeding, contributing to hypokalemia.

Refeeding syndrome:

  • One of the most significant metabolic complications of both parenteral and enteral feeding.
  • This occurs in the first days after feeding is commenced in patients who have been severely malnourished.

The patient is considered to be at risk of developing refeeding syndrome with EITHER.

One or more of the following: (OR)

Two or more of the following:

BMI <16 kg/m2

BMI <18.5 kg/m2

Unintentional weight loss >15% within the last 3-6 months

Unintentional weight loss >10% within the last 3-6 months.

Little or no nutritional intake for more than 10 days

Little or no nutritional intake for more than 5 days.

Low potassium, phosphate or magnesium levels prior to feeding

History of alcohol abuse or on medication, including insulin, chemotherapy, antacids or diuretics.

 

Mechanism of Refeeding Syndrome:

Electrolyte abnormalities:

  • Hypophosphatemia (Option D)
  • Hypomagnesemia
  • Hypokalemia (Option A)
  • Hypocalcemia (Option C)

This leads to arrhythmia, confusion, and respiratory failure, ultimately leading to death.

Management:

  • Matching the intake with requirements.
  • Avoid overfeeding
  • Calorie delivery should be increased slowly
  • Vitamin administration (Thiamine): Given before feeding.
  • Electrolyte abnormalities should be corrected

questions.text: A patient following a road traffic accident (RTA) with a crush injury presents with crepitus and a reddish-brown wound within 3 days after amputation. What is the most likely condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Gas gangrene

Explanation:

  • Gas gangrene is caused by Clostridium species, typically after traumatic injuries, especially with crush wounds or amputation. It is characterized by crepitus (gas production), reddish-brown discoloration of the wound, and rapid progression within days.

Gas Gangrene

A rapidly progressive, potentially fatal condition characterized by widespread necrosis of muscles and soft-tissue destruction, often due to late-presenting missile wounds or crushing injuries.

Cause

Clostridium perfringens

Incubation period

<24 hours but ranges from 1 hour to 6 weeks

Sources and predisposing factors
  • Contaminated soil and feces.
  • Wounds with necrotic or foreign material.
  • Crush wounds, road traffic accidents, amputations.
  • Anaerobic environments in the wound.

Common sites of infection
  • Adductor region of the lower limb and buttocks.
  • Subscapular region in the upper limb.

Clinical features
  • Severe pain with limb swelling rapidly increases in severity.
  • Serosanguineous discharge.
  • Skin turns brown to blue-black with hemorrhagic bullae.
  • Sweet, sticky odor & Soft-tissue crepitus.

Complication

  • Septicaemia, toxemia, renal failure, liver failure.
  • Circulatory failure, DIC, secondary infections.
  • Death occurs in critically ill patients.

Investigation

  • X-ray: Gas in soft tissues.
  • Gram stain & blood culture: Large Gram-positive bacilli without neutrophils.
  • Biochemical profile: Metabolic acidosis, renal failure.
  • Peripheral blood smear: Haemolysis.
  • CT scan for chest or abdominal wounds.

Treatment

  • High-dose intravenous penicillin and clindamycin, along with 3rd generation cephalosporins, are given intravenously.
  • Polyvalent antiserums given intravenously.
  • All dead tissues are excised, and debridement is performed until healthy tissue bleeds.
  • Amputation done in severe cases
  • Hyperbaric oxygen therapy.

Prevention

  • Proper debridement of devitalized crushed wounds.
  • Devitalized wounds should not be sutured.
  • Adequate cleaning of wounds with H₂O₂ and normal saline.
  • Penicillin - As a prophylactic antibiotic.

Image

Incorrect Options:

Impetigo (Option B) is a superficial skin infection caused by Streptococcus or Staphylococcus bacteria, presenting as honey-colored crusts, but does not typically cause crepitus or involve deep tissue.

Tetanus (Option C) results from infection with Clostridium tetani, leading to muscle stiffness and spasms. While it follows a traumatic injury, it doesn’t typically present with crepitus or reddish-brown wound discoloration.

Cellulitis (Option D) is a bacterial skin infection that causes redness, swelling, and warmth, but it does not produce crepitus or reddish-brown wounds and typically develops over a longer period.

questions.text: Arrange the stages of wound healing in the correct sequence:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Hemostasis, inflammation, proliferation, remodeling

Explanation:

Wound healing occurs in four stages: hemostasis, inflammation, proliferation, and remodeling.

  • Hemostasis:
    • Occurs immediately after injury: vasoconstriction, platelet aggregation, and clot formation.
    • Platelets release growth factors (e.g., TGF-β, PDGF, VEGF) that promote matrix deposition, chemotaxis, and angiogenesis.
    • Coagulation cascade leads to thrombin formation, stabilizing the platelet plug.
  • Inflammation:
    • Early Phase (Days 1-2): Neutrophils clear debris and fight infection. Vasoactive amines increase vascular permeability.
    • Late Phase (Days 2-3): Macrophages debride the wound, release growth factors, and promote fibroblast and angiogenesis.
    • Cardinal signs: rubor (redness), tumor (swelling), calor (heat), dolor (pain).
  • Proliferation:
    • Days 3-14: Fibroblasts produce collagen and extracellular matrix. Granulation tissue forms, and angiogenesis occurs.
    • Myofibroblasts help contract the wound and bring edges together.
  • Remodelling:
    • Weeks to months: Type III collagen is replaced by stronger type I collagen.
    • The wound reaches about 80% of normal skin strength by 12 weeks and continues to mature for up to a year.

questions.text: Which of the following is considered a “sure sign” of abdominal wound dehiscence in a post-operative hypotensive patient?

choices.text: Widening of the abdominal scar with palpable edges

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Serosanguinous drainage from the wound

Explanation:

Serosanguinous drainage from the wound is considered a "sure sign" of abdominal wound dehiscence in a post-operative hypotensive patient (Salmon fluid sign)

Wound dehiscence is the disruption of any or all layers of a wound. It occurs in up to 3% of abdominal wounds and is associated with an increased risk of postoperative mortality.

  • Timing and Presentation:
    • Wound dehiscence typically occurs 5 to 8 days postoperatively when the strength of the wound is at its weakest.
    • It often presents with serosanguinous discharge and may be preceded by a popping sensation felt by the patient, particularly during activities like straining or coughing.
    • The dehiscence may also indicate an underlying abscess.
  • Risk factors:
    • Poor wound closure or closure under tension
    • Infection, hematoma, or seroma at the wound site
    • Increased intra-abdominal pressure, e.g., in postoperative patients with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) or excessive coughing
    • Malnourishment
    • Diabetes
    • Obesity
    • Renal failure
    • Jaundice
    • Sepsis
    • Cancer
    • Steroid use
    • Emergency surgery
  • Management:
    • Full-thickness dehiscence generally requires the patient to return to the operating room for resuturing.
    • In cases of infected tissues, poor-quality tissue, or wounds under excessive tension, the wound may be left open and managed with dressings or vacuum-assisted closure (VAC).

questions.text: An elderly chronic smoker male is diagnosed with squamous cell carcinoma of the lower lip with no lymph node involvement. What is the treatment of choice?

choices.text: Wide local excision with negative borders
Wide local excision with frozen section

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Wide local excision with negative borders

Explanation:

Wide local excision with frozen section is the treatment of choice for early-stage squamous cell carcinoma of the lower lip in patients with no lymph node involvement. This technique ensures that the excision margins are clear in real-time, reducing the risk of recurrence.

Cutaneous Squamous Cell Carcinoma (SCC): SCC is a malignant tumor of keratinising cells in the epidermis, commonly arising from the stratum basalis. It is the second most common skin cancer, more prevalent in fair-skinned individuals with chronic sun exposure.

  • Risk factors:
    • UV radiation, chronic inflammation, immunosuppression, chemical carcinogens (e.g., arsenic), and HPV infection (types 5 and 16).
    • Tobacco use doubles the risk.
  • Precursor lesions:
    • Actinic Keratosis (AK): Dysplastic lesions from sun damage; 20% progress to SCC.
    • Keratin Horns: Raised keratinous surface from AK, 10% may have underlying SCC.
    • Keratoacanthomas: Rapidly growing, nodular tumors that resemble SCC and should be excised.
  • Clinical features:
    • SCC presents as nodular, verrucous, or ulcerating lesions with an everted edge and surrounding induration.
  • Differential diagnosis: AK, BCC, pyoderma gangrenosum, and warts.
  • Microscopic features: Irregular squamous epithelium invading the dermis, positive for cytokeratins 1 and 10. Broders' grading assesses tumor differentiation.
  • Management: The primary treatment for SCC is surgical excision, which provides accurate histological diagnosis and clear margins. The size of the SCC influences the required margin:
    • <2 cm SCC: 4 mm margin
    • >2 cm SCC: 1 cm margin
  • The recurrence rate is approximately 20%.
  • Surgical excision is the only reliable method for ensuring clear margins. Mohs’ micrographic surgery may be indicated for difficult-to-resect tumours or those with recurrent SCC.

questions.text: A female patient presents to the outpatient department 10 days postpartum with complaints of a fluctuant breast mass with tenderness, high-grade fever, and cracked nipples. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Breast abscess

Explanation:

  • A breast abscess is a localized collection of pus within the breast tissue, most commonly seen in lactating women. The patient's clinical presentation, including a fluctuant mass, high fever, and localized tenderness, strongly suggests this diagnosis.

Breast Abscess

Definition
  • Pus-filled cavity within breast tissue.

Types
  • Lactational Abscess: Associated with breastfeeding.
  • Non-Lactational Abscess: Occurs in non-lactating women, e.g., periductal mastitis.

Causes and Risk Factors
  • Lactation:
    • Incidence: 3% to 20% in lactating mothers.
    • Common pathogen: Staphylococcus aureus (methicillin-resistant strains in hospital settings).
    • Entry points: Cracked/retracted nipple, blocked lactiferous ducts.
  • Non-Lactation:
    • Often in nulliparous women or post-lactation.
    • Conditions: Periductal mastitis, idiopathic granulomatous mastitis, tubercular mastitis.
    • Smoking and diabetes as risk factors.

Signs and symptoms

Fever, leukocytosis, erythema, pain and tenderness, swelling, malaise, difficulty feeding, enlarged and tender axillary nodes

Diagnosis
  • Ultrasonography:
    • Detects cellulitis, liquefaction necrosis.
    • Confirms abscess size, location, and loculation.

Treatment
  • Lactational Mastitis:
    • Antibiotics: Anti-staphylococcal (e.g., cloxacillin, flucloxacillin, erythromycin).
    • Breast emptying: Frequent breastfeeding or pumping.
    • Support: Breast support garment, cold compresses, analgesia.
    • Drainage: Ultrasound-guided preferred over surgical incision.
    • Follow-up: Regular clinical and ultrasonographic reviews, culture-based antibiotic modification.
  • Non-Lactational Mastitis:
    • Broad-spectrum antibiotics for subareolar infections.
    • Needle aspiration for abscess drainage.
    • Major milk duct excision for complications like sepsis or fistula.

Incorrect Options:

Breast engorgement (Option A) is not associated with a fluctuant mass, high fever, or localized pain.

Acute mastitis (Option C) can cause breast pain and swelling, but it typically does not present as a fluctuant mass.

Fibroadenoma (Option D) does not present with a fluctuant mass, high fever, or localized pain.

questions.text: Identify the test provided in the image below.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Allen’s test

Explanation:

The given image shows Allen’s test.

Allen's Test is a clinical manoeuvre used to assess the blood flow to the hand, specifically evaluating the patency of the radial and ulnar arteries. It is commonly used before procedures like inserting an arterial line or taking a blood sample from the radial artery.

  • Procedure:
    • The patient is asked to make a fist, compressing the radial and ulnar arteries simultaneously.
    • The patient is then asked to open their hand (which should appear pale).
    • Once the hand is open, the examiner releases one of the arteries (usually the ulnar artery).
    • The test is positive if normal colour returns to the hand quickly (within 5-10 seconds), indicating adequate collateral circulation.
  • If there is a delay in the colour return or no return, this may suggest compromised blood flow through the released artery, which could indicate arterial occlusion & the radial artery should not be pricked.

 

Adson's test (Option B) is used to diagnose thoracic outlet syndrome (TOS), which occurs due to compression of the brachial plexus or subclavian artery in the thoracic outlet.

  • The patient is instructed to extend their neck and turn their head toward the arm being tested while the examiner palpates the radial pulse. The patient then takes a deep breath. A positive test is indicated by a reduction or disappearance of the radial pulse, suggesting compression in the thoracic outlet.

 

Elevated Arm Stress Test (Option C) evaluates thoracic outlet syndrome by assessing the compression of neurovascular structures in the thoracic outlet.

  • The patient’s arms are raised above the head and held for 1-2 minutes. A positive test occurs if the patient experiences symptoms of numbness, tingling, or a decrease in the radial pulse, which indicates compression of the neurovascular bundle in the thoracic outlet.

 

Nicoladoni's test (Option D) is used to assess for increased intracranial pressure (ICP) or brainstem compression.

  • The test is positive if the patient exhibits a sudden drop in pulse or blood pressure when their head is tilted backwards (in a hyperextended position).

questions.text: A patient presents to the emergency room after a road traffic accident with shock and hypotension. The extended focused assessment with sonography for trauma (eFAST) is negative, the X-ray is normal, and the ECG shows no abnormalities. The patient's SpO2 is 93%, blood pressure is 80/60 mmHg, and pulse rate is 40/min. Based on this information, what type of shock is most likely?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Neurogenic shock

Explanation:

  • Neurogenic shock is characterized by hypotension, bradycardia (low pulse rate), and normal or slightly reduced SpO2. The absence of trauma to solid organs, negative eFAST, and normal X-rays help rule out hemorrhagic or cardiogenic shock. The bradycardia (pulse of 40/min) is due to a loss of sympathetic tone following spinal cord injury or severe trauma, leading to vasodilation and bradycardia.

Neurogenic shock:

  • In neurogenic shock, there is a loss of sympathetic tone, leading to vasodilation of the peripheral vasculature, resulting in decreased peripheral vascular resistance and hypotension. This is the primary mechanism underlying neurogenic shock.

Causes:

  • Neurogenic shock is a critical condition that results from the dysregulation of the autonomic nervous system following spinal cord injury, especially in the cervical and upper thoracic vertebrae above the T6 level, as a result of traumatic events. The dysregulation arises due to the lack of sympathetic tone and decreased peripheral vascular resistance.
  • The decline in sympathetic tone prompts the dilation of capacitance blood vessels in the lower extremities. This, in turn, results in decreased cardiac filling, leading to hypotension and shock.
  • Reduced sympathetic control over the heart leads to a situation where unopposed vagal cardiac influence causes bradycardia.
  • Patients with neurogenic shock may also exhibit pink and warm skin due to the dilation of subcutaneous blood vessels.
  • Severe brain injury.
  • Certain anaesthetics.

Pathophysiology

Clinical Manifestations:

  • Hypotension
  • Bradycardia (unlike other forms of shock)
  • Warm, dry skin below injury level
  • Priapism in males
  • Respiratory compromise (if high cervical injury)
  • Poikilothermia (inability to regulate body temperature)

questions.text: A 25-year-old male patient is brought to the casualty after a road traffic accident (RTA) with suspected pelvic fractures. On examination, he is found to be in hypovolemic shock. What is the earliest treatment for control of haemorrhage in this case?

choices.text: Use bedsheets to compress the pelvis

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Use bedsheets to compress the pelvis

Explanation:

In the case of pelvic fractures with suspected haemorrhage and hypovolemic shock, pelvic compression is a critical step to control bleeding and stabilise the patient.

  • Using bedsheets (or a pelvic binder) to compress the pelvis helps reduce the volume of the pelvic cavity, which in turn minimises bleeding from the fractured vessels and improves hemodynamic stability.

Management of Pelvic fractures: The primary goal in managing pelvic fractures with bleeding is to stop the bleeding, as these injuries pose a significant threat to circulation.

  • Initial management: The first step is applying a compression binder or sheet around the true pelvis at the level of the greater trochanters to reduce pelvic volume. This life-saving procedure should be performed in the emergency department immediately.

  • Bleeding sources:
    • Venous Bleeding (85% of cases): Most bleeding originates from veins, which can be controlled non-operatively using pelvic compression (via binding or external fixators). Another technique is extraperitoneal pelvic packing, where the space between the bony pelvis and the peritoneum is packed to compress veins.
    • Arterial Bleeding: If bleeding is arterial in origin, angiographic embolisation becomes the next choice for controlling haemorrhage.
  • Techniques such as compression, packing, fixation, and angiography may be used together, as they can complement one another. If bleeding persists after packing, angiography or other interventions may be necessary.
  • If the source of bleeding is unclear, or if diagnostic imaging (FAST/CT) shows significant blood in the peritoneal cavity, an exploratory laparotomy is warranted to rule out or address concurrent intra-abdominal injuries.

questions.text: A soldier arrives at a referral hospital 24 hours after experiencing a shrapnel injury to his right thigh caused by a high-speed projectile. He expresses significant discomfort at the site of the wound. Upon examination, there is evidence of crepitus. Which of the following microorganisms is the probable culprit behind his current state?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Clostridium perfringens

Explanation:

  • The soldier's shrapnel injury to his right thigh, accompanied by significant discomfort, crepitus (presence of gas in the tissues), suggests Gas Gangrene caused by Clostridium perfringens.

Explanation:

The surest sign of Wound Dehiscence following emergency laparotomy is copious serosanguinous discharge, typically occurring around day 6 post-op, indicating a burst abdomen and requiring urgent laparotomy management.

Definition

Disruption of any or all of the layers in a wound.

Occurrence

Up to 3% of abdominal wounds; most commonly occurs between the 5th and 8th postoperative days.

Types

 
  1. Partial dehiscence: Involves only the skin and subcutaneous fat.
  2. Complete dehiscence: Involves the fascial layer and may include evisceration (extrusion of abdominal viscera).

General:

  • Malnourishment
  • Diabetes
  • Obesity
  • Renal failure
  • Jaundice
  • Sepsis
  • Cancer
  • Treatment with steroids
  • Emergency surgery

Local:

  • Inadequate or poor closure of wound or closure of a wound under tension
  • Poor local wound healing
  • Increased intra-abdominal pressure

Clinical Presentation
  • Pinkish serosanguinous discharge (salmon-coloured fluid), (Option A)
  • Possible evisceration,
  • Popping sensation during straining or coughing.

Treatment

  • Partial dehiscence (without evisceration): Prompt reclosure of the fascia is generally advised.
  • Complete dehiscence with evisceration:
    • Requires urgent reoperation.
    • Tension suturing is done.
    • Protect eviscerated bowel with moist towels; handle carefully to prevent injury.
    • Antibiotic therapy; fluid management.

Hypotension (Option D) may occur due to various factors like shock, blood loss, or infection. While hypotension can be a result of complications following surgery, it is a general sign of systemic distress rather than a specific sign of wound dehiscence. The cause of hypotension needs to be identified through further clinical investigation.

Correct Answer: A) Incision and drainage

Explanation:

Breast Abscess

Definition
  • Pus-filled cavity within breast tissue.

Types
  • Lactational Abscess: Associated with breastfeeding.
  • Non-Lactational Abscess: Occurs in non-lactating women, e.g., periductal mastitis.

Causes and Risk Factors
  • Lactation:
    • Incidence: 3% to 20% in lactating mothers.
    • Common pathogen: Staphylococcus aureus (methicillin-resistant strains in hospital settings).
    • Entry points: Cracked/retracted nipple, blocked lactiferous ducts.
  • Non-Lactation:
    • Often in nulliparous women or post-lactation.
    • Conditions: Periductal mastitis, idiopathic granulomatous mastitis, tubercular mastitis.
    • Smoking and diabetes as risk factors.

Signs and symptoms

Fever, leukocytosis, erythema, pain and tenderness, swelling, malaise, difficulty feeding, enlarged and tender axillary nodes

Diagnosis
  • Ultrasonography:
    • Detects cellulitis, liquefaction necrosis.
    • Confirms abscess size, location, and loculation.

Treatment
  • Lactational Mastitis:
    • Antibiotics: Anti-staphylococcal (e.g., cloxacillin, flucloxacillin, erythromycin).
    • Breast emptying: Frequent breastfeeding or pumping.
    • Support: Breast support garment, cold compresses, analgesia.
    • Drainage: Ultrasound-guided preferred over surgical incision.
    • Follow-up: Regular clinical and ultrasonographic reviews, culture-based antibiotic modification.
  • Non-Lactational Mastitis:
    • Broad-spectrum antibiotics for subareolar infections.
    • Needle aspiration for abscess drainage.
    • Major milk duct excision for complications like sepsis or fistula.

Broad-spectrum antibiotics (Option B) may be used in conjunction with incision and drainage to treat the infection, but antibiotics alone are not sufficient for the management of a Breast abscess.

Breast conservation surgery (Option C) typically involves the removal of a breast lump or tumor. Thus, breast conservation surgery is not appropriate management option for a breast abscess.

Breastfeeding, nipple trauma (cracks), poor latch, prolonged engorgement

Fever, malaise, painful swollen breast, erythema, bloody or purulent discharge

Tender indurated mass, warmth, erythema over the affected breast

Breast abscess (if untreated)

Frequent breastfeeding, warm compress, analgesics, antibiotics (dicloxacillin, cephalexin)

Fibrocystic disease (Option D): Incorrect because it causes cyclic breast pain and nodularity, typically worsening before menstruation, not postpartum infection.

questions.text: What is the ideal pressure setting for vacuum-assisted closure (VAC) therapy?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - 125 mm Hg:

  • This is the most commonly recommended and studied pressure setting for VAC therapy. It is considered ideal for promoting wound healing, reducing edema, and enhancing blood flow while minimizing tissue damage. Most clinical guidelines and studies support this pressure as the optimal setting for standard VAC therapy.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - 60 to 80 mm Hg: This lower pressure range may be used in specific situations, such as when treating wounds over sensitive or delicate areas where higher pressures might cause discomfort or tissue damage. However, it is generally not considered the ideal setting for most VAC applications.

Option C - 130 mm Hg: Although close to the recommended pressure, this slightly higher setting may increase the risk of tissue damage and discomfort, making it less ideal compared to the 125 mm Hg setting.

Option D - 80 to 100 mm Hg: This range may be used for certain wounds where a lower pressure is needed, such as in patients with compromised circulation or delicate tissues. However, it is not the standard pressure setting for VAC therapy in most cases.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male with a history of a road traffic accident presents to the emergency department. His GCS is 8/15, oxygen saturation is 85%, blood pressure is 100/60 mmHg and heart rate is 60 beats per minute. On examination, breath sounds are absent on the right side. What is the next step in management?

choices.text: Start IV fluids, give atropine and secure airway
Secure airway, give oxygen, insert ICD, secure IV line
Evaluate for head injury and do CT-head
﻿﻿﻿Administer IV dextrose followed by NCCT head

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Secure airway, give oxygen, insert ICD, secure IV line

Explanation:

  • The patient has GCS 8/15, indicating a severe head injury and possible impaired consciousness. Therefore, securing the airway is the priority to prevent further deterioration.
  • Oxygen should be administered to address the low oxygen saturation (85%).
  • The absence of breath sounds on the right side raises concern for tension pneumothorax or large pneumothorax, which can lead to respiratory failure.
  • In this case, the next step is to insert an intercostal chest drain (ICD) to relieve any pneumothorax and re-expand the lung.
  • IV access should be secured for fluid resuscitation or medication administration, but airway and breathing take precedence.
  • We will follow a primary survey of A, B, C, D, and E to manage this patient, where A is securing the airway, B is giving oxygen and inserting ICD, and C includes IV line.
     

Start IV fluids, give atropine and secure airway (Option A):

  • Securing the airway is important, but giving atropine is not the priority here because the patient has a heart rate of 60 bpm, which is not significantly low and does not require atropine at this stage.

 

Evaluate for head injury and do CT-head (Option C):

  • The immediate concern is the airway and respiratory distress.
  • The absence of breath sounds on the right side suggests a life-threatening thoracic injury that should be managed first, with a CT scan of the head being considered later once the patient is stabilised.

 

Administer IV dextrose followed by NCCT head (Option D):

  • There is no indication that the patient is hypoglycemic or in need of IV dextrose at this moment.
  • The priority should be stabilising the airway and managing the potential pneumothorax.
  • The NCCT head can be done later if head injury is suspected after stabilizing the patient.

questions.text: Which of the following is a complication of Total Parenteral Nutrition (TPN) in a sepsis patient in the ICU?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Hyperglycemia:

  • This is a frequent complication of TPN, particularly in critically ill patients, such as those with sepsis (metabolic disorders). The high glucose content of TPN, combined with insulin resistance often seen in sepsis, can lead to significant elevations in blood glucose levels.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Hyperlipidemia: TPN can sometimes lead to elevated lipid levels, especially if the lipid component is administered in excess. However, this is less common in the acute setting of a septic patient compared to hyperglycemia.

Option C - Hyperglyceridemia: While TPN contains lipids that can elevate glyceride levels, hyperglyceridemia is not as common or clinically significant as hyperglycemia in the acute management of sepsis.

Option D - Hypoglycemia: Although hypoglycemia can occur if TPN is suddenly stopped or if there is an insulin overdose, it is not a common complication during the administration of TPN, especially in a septic patient where hyperglycemia is more likely.

questions.text: Which of the following is characteristic of hypovolemic shock?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) High vascular resistance

Explanation:

In Hypovolemic shock, as the body tries to compensate for the reduced blood volume, the blood vessels constrict (vasoconstriction) to preserve blood pressure and redirect blood flow to vital organs like the heart and brain. This results in increased vascular resistance.

  • Decreased cardiac output (Option A): Since there's less blood to pump, the heart cannot maintain a normal cardiac output. This is opposite to what happens in some other types of shock (e.g., septic shock), where cardiac output may initially increase.
  • Decreased venous pressure (Option C): Lower blood volume means less blood returning to the heart, leading to reduced venous pressure.
  • Decreased mixed venous saturation (Option D): In hypovolemic shock, oxygen delivery is impaired, and the blood returning to the heart has a lower oxygen saturation, which is reflected in a lower mixed venous oxygen saturation.

questions.text: A 30-year-old female who is receiving cyclosporine A following renal transplantation develops multiple and bilateral breast lumps that regress after cessation of the treatment. Biopsy image is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Fibroadenoma

Explanation:

  • The biopsy image shows a proliferation of ducts arranged in both intracanalicular and pericanalicular patterns, surrounded by fibromyxoid stroma, suggesting Fibroadenoma. These tumours are common in young women, and hormonal changes may influence their growth. Cyclosporine A, which has hormonal effects, could contribute to the development of fibroadenoma.

Fibroadenoma:

  • It is the most common benign breast tumour, typically found in women aged 15-35.
  • Characteristics: Spherical masses measuring 1-10 cm, firm, non-tender, well-circumscribed, mobile and often single.
  • The lump is mobile and slippery and hence called breast mouse.
  • Estrogen sensitivity: Can increase in size during pregnancy, lactation, or estrogen therapy and usually regress after menopause.
  • HPE: Well-defined borders due to a fibrous capsule, with proliferating stroma potentially compressing and distorting glandular components.
  • Popcorn calcification on mammogram.
  • Ageing effect: Epithelium atrophies with age, and the stroma becomes more hyalinised.
  • Molecular alteration: Alterations in MED12 gene
  • Drug associated with bilateral fibroadenomas: Cyclosporine

The histological features of a fibroadenoma include:

  1. Fibroepithelial tumours are composed of benign-appearing cellular or myxoid stroma encircling epithelium-lined glands and cystic spaces.
  2. Staghorn clusters of cells - Ductal cells arranged in a deer horn-like pattern
  3. Bare nuclei - cytoplasm is stripped of,f and only nuclei are visible in blue colour.

Incorrect Options:

Fat necrosis (Option A) typically presents with firm, tender breast lumps following trauma or surgery and shows fatty tissue changes on biopsy, not ductal proliferation.

Phyllodes tumour (Option B) can have similar histological features with ductal proliferation but is typically more cellular and can have a leaf-like architecture. It also tends to grow rapidly and is more common in older women.

Carcinoma breast (Option D) would be expected to present with more aggressive histological features, such as invasion of surrounding tissue and atypical cells, rather than benign ductal proliferation.

questions.text: A 65-year-old male presents to the outpatient department with a swelling in the back of his neck that has been present for almost a year. The swelling has not increased in size. On examination, it is non-pulsatile, and the slip sign is positive, with the swelling measuring 3x3 cm. Which of the following statements is most likely true?

choices.text: Excision can be done if the patient requests it

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Excision can be done if the patient requests it

Explanation:

  • Based on the clinical features (non-pulsatile, stable size, and positive slip sign), this is most likely a lipoma, which is a benign tumour of fatty tissue. If the patient requests excision, and if there are no concerns about malignancy, excision can be performed to remove the lipoma for cosmetic or symptomatic reasons.

Lipoma:

  • A lipoma is a benign tumour composed of mature adipocytes (fat cells) and is the most common soft tissue tumor.
  • These tumors are generally soft, mobile, and painless masses found beneath the skin.
  • Most frequently found on the trunk, shoulders, neck, and arms.
  • Histologically, lipomas consist of mature fat cells that are identical to normal adipose tissue but are encapsulated by a thin fibrous capsule, distinguishing them from the surrounding tissue.
  • Lipomas are typically slow-growing, soft, and non-tender.
  • They are usually asymptomatic but can cause discomfort if they compress nearby structures or are located in a site prone to friction or pressure.
  • On physical examination, lipomas are well-circumscribed, mobile masses that can vary in size from a few millimetres to several centimetres.
  • Slip sign: Positive
  • Very low risk of malignant transformation into liposarcoma. (Option A)

 

Management:

  • Most lipomas do not require treatment unless they become symptomatic, grow rapidly, or cause cosmetic concerns.
  • Surgical excision is the definitive treatment and is usually curative.
  • Liposuction may also be an option for larger lipomas, but complete excision is preferred to prevent recurrence.

While FNAC can be used for diagnosing soft tissue masses, it is not always required if the lesion's clinical presentation is typical of a lipoma. In many cases, a clinical diagnosis based on history and examination (such as soft, mobile, non-tender mass) is sufficient. (Option B)

PET scans are generally used for staging known malignancies, such as lymphoma or other aggressive cancers. In this case, there is no indication that this is a malignant lesion, so a PET scan is unnecessary. (Option C)

questions.text: A 47-year-old man presents with a chronic non-healing painless ulcer over his scalp for 8 years. He has a history of electric burns to the scalp 8 years ago. The examination findings are shown below. Which of the following statements is true?

choices.text: It can progress to squamous cell carcinoma
Long-duration antibiotics will improve the condition.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) It can progress to squamous cell carcinoma

Explanation:

Chronic non-healing ulcers, especially those resulting from burn injuries or other trauma, are at high risk of malignant transformation, most commonly to squamous cell carcinoma (SCC). This is known as Marjolin's ulcer, which can develop in areas of chronic injury or scar tissue.

Marjolin’s Ulcer

Definition
  • Low-grade Squamous Cell Carcinoma (SCC)

Common Sites of Development
  • Post-burn scar
  • Long-standing venous ulcer
  • Chronic ulcer due to trauma
  • Chronic discharging osteomyelitis sinus
  • Post-radiation ulcer

Pathophysiology
  • Develops in scar tissue due to chronic irritation

Characteristic Features
  • Painless (no nerves in scar tissues)
  • Slow growing
  • No regional LN metastasis (no lymphatics in scar tissue)

Investigation of Choice

Biopsy

Management
  • Wide local excision followed by a flap cover
  • Radiotherapy should be avoided (Option A) (as it is radio-resistant and also to prevent obliterative end arteritis)
  • Malignant lesions like squamous cell carcinoma can spread via lymphatic channels (Option C), particularly if left untreated.
  • While antibiotics may help treat an infected ulcer, a chronic non-healing ulcer with a history of burn injury is unlikely to respond to antibiotics alone (Option D).

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman presents with severe pain and swelling in her right hand, which is increasing in size and severity. She had a prick injury in the garden 5 days ago. On examination, she cries out in pain when her hand is extended and when the palmar aspect is palpated passively. Which of the following statements is true about the condition?

choices.text: More common in the dorsal aspect of the hand
X-ray imaging will aid in the location of the foreign body in all patients
Oral analgesics are the mainstay of treatment

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) It requires incision and drainage

Explanation:

The patient likely has a deep palmar abscess secondary to a foreign body, and incision and drainage (I&D) is required to relieve pressure, remove the foreign body, and treat the infection.

Deep Palmar Infection: These infections begin in the palm and may be confined to a web space initially. As the infection progresses, the entire hand becomes swollen and tender due to the accumulation of pus on either side of the septum.

  • Management:
    • The treatment involves incision and drainage (I&D) with a thorough washout of the wound.
    • It's essential to open all affected deep spaces. In some cases, incisions may be needed on both the dorsal and volar sides of the hand.
    • If the extent of the infection is unclear, imaging techniques like ultrasound or MRI can be used to delineate the spread within the deep palmar spaces.

Incorrect Options:

More common in the dorsal aspect of the hand (Option A): Infections or abscesses caused by foreign bodies are more common in the palmar aspect due to the tighter fascial compartments.

X-ray imaging will aid in the location of the foreign body in all patients (Option B): X-rays are not always helpful, especially for non-radio-opaque foreign bodies (wood), so other imaging like ultrasound might be more useful.

Oral analgesics (Option D) may help manage pain, but they are not sufficient for treating the underlying infection/abscess, which requires I&D.

questions.text: A patient fell from a train onto the railway track and injured both his legs severely. He was urgently taken to the hospital, and the following procedure was performed (image shown below). What is the rationale for performing this procedure?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Life-saving procedure

Explanation:

  • In cases of severe trauma, such as being run over or falling on railway tracks, injuries can be so extensive that amputation is necessary to prevent massive blood loss, gangrene, or infection, which can lead to death. The decision for a bilateral below-knee amputation is usually made as a life-saving measure when there is irreversible damage to the legs.

Indications for Amputation:

  • Dead Limb: Gangrene
  • Deadly Limb
    • Wet gangrene
    • Spreading cellulitis
    • Arteriovenous fistula
    • Malignancy (e.g., sarcoma)
  • Dead loss of limb:
    • Severe rest pain due to irreversible critical leg ischemia
    • Paralysis
    • Severe contracture
    • Trauma (irreparable damage)

Local Amputation:

  • For small-vessel disease (e.g., diabetes): Gangrene of toes may require local amputation. If the metatarsophalangeal joint is involved, ray excision may be necessary.

Major Amputation:

  • Below-knee Amputation: Preserves knee joint, offering better prosthetic use.
  • Above-knee Amputation: For poor circulation or non-mobilizing patients.
  • Knee Disarticulation: Preserves femur and patella for better prosthetic function.

Post-operative care:

  • Pain Management: Regular opiate use.
  • Limb Care: Prevent pressure ulcers on the remaining limb.
  • Exercise: Prevent deformities, build strength, and improve mobility.

Complications:

  • Early: Hemorrhage, infection, gas gangrene, and wound dehiscence.
  • Late: Phantom limb pain, stump ulceration, DVT, and pulmonary embolism

questions.text: In solid organ transplantation, which of the following organs is associated with a higher incidence of rejection?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Lungs

Explanation:

  • Survival after lung transplantation continues to improve over time; however, the rates remain lower compared to other solid organ transplants.
  • Around 50% of lung transplant recipients will face at least one episode of acute rejection within the first year.
  • Furthermore, by five years post-transplant, roughly half of recipients will have developed chronic rejection.

Incorrect Options:

Kidney transplantation: (Option C)

  • Graft rejection rate for kidney transplants is quite low after the first year. Specifically, with living-donor kidneys, the 1-year survival rate is 98%, and with deceased-donor kidneys, the 1-year survival rate is 93%.
  • At 5 years, the graft survival rate for living-donor kidneys is 85%, and for deceased-donor kidneys, it is 75%. By 10 years, the survival rates drop to 65% for living-donor kidneys and 48% for deceased-donor kidneys, indicating a gradual decline due to chronic processes rather than acute rejection episodes.

Liver transplantation (Option D): Chronic rejection occurs in about 13-17% of recipients

Intestinal transplantation (Option B): Chronic rejection occurs in about 10% of recipients.

questions.text: A 55-year-old female patient with chronic pancreatitis undergoes a Puestow procedure. What is the most preferred route for supplementary nutrition in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) TPN (Total Parenteral Nutrition)

Explanation:

  • TPN is typically indicated when enteral feeding via the gastrointestinal tract is not possible or not well tolerated.
  • After a Puestow procedure, especially if there are concerns about pancreatic insufficiency, altered gut anatomy, or complications like fistulas.

Post-operative care in patients with chronic pancreatitis following a Puestow procedure:

  • Nutrition: Provide nutrition via TPN (Total Parenteral Nutrition) or jejunostomy feeding, depending on the patient's condition and tolerance.
  • Fluid and electrolyte management: Ensure careful monitoring and correction of fluid and electrolyte balance.
  • Sepsis prevention and control: Take proactive measures to prevent infections and monitor for signs of sepsis regularly.
  • Octreotide use: Administer octreotide during the surgery and continue at regular intervals or as a slow infusion postoperatively for up to 5 days to help reduce pancreatic secretion and minimize complications.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman, 10 years after mastectomy, notices gradual swelling and heaviness in her right upper limb without pain. On examination, bluish nodules on the skin with no infections are noted. What is the most likely cause of her symptoms?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Lymphangiosarcoma

Explanation:

  • Lymphangiosarcoma is the most likely cause of these symptoms, especially in a patient with a history of mastectomy.
  • This condition, also known as Stewart-Treves syndrome, can develop years after mastectomy due to long-standing lymphedema, which is a consequence of lymphatic obstruction.
